questions.question: Advanced AI should be accessible to everyone, not just a select few organizations.
Open-sourcing advanced AI models creates unacceptable security risks for society.
Having more people able to inspect and test an AI system's code makes that system safer and more trustworthy.
The potential misuse of a powerful technology is a good reason to not make it publicly available.
The source code and training data of AI systems should be transparent for public accountability.
It's better if only a few highly regulated companies have access to cutting-edge AI, to prevent it from being misused.
AI labs should withhold extremely powerful AI models from the public until they are confident the models won't cause serious harm.
Developing AI in the open allows a wider range of human values and perspectives to shape it, rather than just one group's values.
Allowing too many voices in AI development will lead to chaotic or inconsistent ethical standards for AI systems.
Open collaboration and sharing in AI research drive innovation more effectively than secretive competition does.
Keeping AI breakthroughs proprietary and secret is necessary to maintain a competitive edge in innovation.
Open-sourcing AI enables smaller players and independent researchers to contribute creative ideas that big labs might miss.
If advanced AI models are freely available, companies will lose the incentive to invest in creating new and better models.
Many of the biggest tech breakthroughs (like the internet) came from open, collaborative efforts – AI should follow that path.
Prioritizing research to ensure AI systems align with human values is critical as AI becomes more powerful.
Concerns that AI will 'turn against' humanity are overhyped – advanced AI will naturally learn to benefit us.
It's worth slowing down or pausing AI development until we're confident we can make it safe and aligned with human values.
Any attempt to slow down AI progress in the name of safety will do more harm than good.
Advanced AI should always remain under strict human supervision and control.
If an AI system can make decisions more effectively than humans, it should be allowed to operate without human intervention.
We must explicitly program moral and ethical principles into AI systems so they reliably do what they 'ought' to do.
Trying to teach human morals to a super-intelligent AI is futile – or could even backfire.
Government regulation is needed to steer AI development and prevent AI from causing serious harm.
AI development should be left to the experts and companies; government interference will only slow progress.
Any AI system that could massively influence society should undergo independent public oversight and testing before deployment.
Market forces and competition – not government rules – will do the most to ensure AI is used responsibly.
Strict limits on what AI can say or do (e.g. to prevent hate speech, violence, etc.) are necessary to keep society safe.
Imposing heavy content filters on AI outputs makes the AI less useful and is essentially a form of censorship.
AI developers have a responsibility to anticipate and prevent any significant harm their technology could cause, even if that slows down development.
Excessive ethical constraints on AI will only hinder its potential benefits to humanity.
Each user community should be free to fine-tune AI systems to align with their own values, rather than having one universal 'moral code' for all AI.
International cooperation and transparency in AI development will yield safer outcomes than an arms race between nations.
It's more important for an AI to tell the unvarnished truth than to avoid saying anything offensive or controversial.
AI models should be treated as public knowledge (like science), not as proprietary corporate secrets.
The real danger with AI is not that it will decide to harm us, but that humans will misuse it for harmful purposes.
The potential benefits of AI far outweigh the potential risks.
I trust the leading AI companies to make the right choices about when and how to release advanced AI technology.
I'd rather an AI be overly cautious — even refusing certain requests — than have it take actions that might be dangerous or unethical.
Releasing AI models into the real world – even if they aren't perfectly aligned – is necessary to discover and fix their problems.
For national security reasons, it's better if cutting-edge AI developments remain classified or restricted, rather than shared openly with the world.
